Everyone give a standing O to the winners of our final MacBook Pro giveaway: Marty R. and Sheryl K. And to readers who shared the Brew far and wide but didn’t win the computer, we hope that earning free swag is an adequate consolation prize. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Now, we <em>said</em> yesterday would be the last day of the laptop giveaway, BUT…</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/06/nycs-new-broker-fee-rule-means?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
NYC Is Feeling StreetUneasy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="New York City apartment " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTgxMDI4NTgxLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">New York City has about 5.6 million renters, and if you gather them all in one room, you’ll end up with roughly 5.6 million complaints and 0.5 nice things to say. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As one of the most expensive rental markets in the world, the city’s real estate “quirks”—like skyscraper-high broker fees—have angered renters for years. But that might be changing. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Broker or broken</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last year, state regulators passed renter protections that capped application fees at $20 and security deposits at one month’s rent. On Tuesday night, they clarified those rules and casually slipped in an announcement that <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/05/nyregion/nyc-landlord-rental-broker-fees.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">renters can no longer be charged</a> broker fees, the NYT reports. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What are those? </strong>Brokers manage apartment listings, viewing appointments, and leases. They have almighty leverage over NYC renters because 1) inventory is so tight and 2) many landlords choose not to list units directly or deal with annoying prospective tenants. For their services, brokers collect fees of up to 15% of the annual lease. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>For context, in December 2019 </span><span><a href="https://www.elliman.com/pdf/292b1b03c463ef570869fa2e601de1ef307d0a22?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">average monthly rent</a></span><span> was $4,412 in Manhattan, $3,410 in Brooklyn, and $3,022 in Queens, according to Douglas Elliman. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Brokers can still collect fees, but they’ll have to pry it from landlords. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">More controversial than a cinnamon and lox bagel?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Proponents of the change say it will protect tenants, lower barriers to housing, and reduce NYC's homeless population.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But critics—otherwise known as the real estate industry—have other thoughts. They claim the rule will disproportionately hurt small building owners who rely on brokers and upend a system that sustains 25,000+ licensed brokers. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Others predict the fees will be passed down to tenants by landlords raising prices. Around 1 million apartments in the city are rent-regulated, but 900,000+ aren’t—and those units could potentially <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/alyyale/2020/02/06/nyc-renters-say-goodbye-to-broker-fees-landlords-poised-to-pick-up-the-slack/#32415d3b15a4?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">face higher rents</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the Real Estate Board of New York threatened to challenge the rule on legal grounds. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F02%2F06%2Fnycs-new-broker-fee-rule-means" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
IPO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/06/casper-valuation-tosses-turns-public-market-debut?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Casper Valuation Tosses and Turns
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Hey Arnold sleeping " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=490 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/qRf7qdK1OTUMU/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Hey Arnold sleeping " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/qRf7qdK1OTUMU/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, mattress-by-mail company Casper Sleep <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/casper-prices-ipo-222615705.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">went public</a> on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol CSPR. Shares gained 12.5% on the day, but that's like scoring a goal when you're already down 6–0. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Casper opened for trading at $14.50 per share when it had initially aimed to go public at a range of $17-$19.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In 2019, private investors gave Casper a valuation of $1.1 billion. It began yesterday with a valuation of less than $600 million.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Hotshot startups are answering for years of bloated private valuations. Last year’s crop of IPOs featured a series of massive, unprofitable companies (see: Uber, Lyft, Peloton) that tripped and fell when subjected to public scrutiny. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The disrupter may become the disrupted—Casper isn’t just competing with Big Mattress anymore. Dozens of upstarts like Purple and Walmart’s Allswell <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/05/casper-cuts-expected-ipo-price-range-to-12-13-a-share-from-17-19-a-share.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">are now vying</a> for a spot in the “sleep economy.”</p>

<tr>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INVESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/06/elliott-ups-stake-softbank-pushes-vision-fund-transparency?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
SoftBank Has a Secret Life Coach
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Paul Singer " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTUzL3BhdWxfc2luZ2VyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>World Economic Forum, The Global Financial Context Paul Singer, CC BY-SA 2.0</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, we learned <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/elliott-management-builds-more-than-2-5-billion-stake-in-softbank-11581015340?mod=breakingnews&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">three new pieces of info</a> about the activist hedge fund Elliott Management, courtesy of the WSJ. </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Elliott has invested over $2.5 billion in Japanese conglomerate SoftBank. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Elliott ratcheted up that investment recently. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Elliott has politely weighed in on SoftBank’s portfolio and governance decisions. </span></li>
</ol>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Elliott’s advice to SoftBank</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For one, buy back stock. Elliott <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/06/elliott-management-invests-more-than-2point5-billion-in-softbank-wsj.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">recommended repurchasing</a> $10–$20 billion to close the not-tiny gap between SoftBank’s market value and the value of its stakes in major players like Chinese internet giant Alibaba, Uber, and Slack. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Second, Elliott is reportedly pushing SoftBank to improve transparency and investment decisions at its controversial $100 billion Vision Fund.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Elliott is known for bossing bosses around. Founded and owned by billionaire Paul Singer, Elliott isn’t shy about telling the Jack Dorseys of the world how to tie their Allbirds. In November, SoftBank took the biggest quarterly loss in its history, driven mainly by a $4.7 billion writedown on one of its biggest bets—WeWork.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/06/google-maps-turns-15-new-icon-new-features?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Six More Years Until Google Maps Can Search for "Bars"
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Google Maps's new icon " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTc2L2dvb2dsZV9tYXBzX3NfbmV3X2ljb24ucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Google</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Tomorrow night Google Maps will celebrate 15 years of helping roadtrippers find their way to the nearest public bathroom. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Google is <a href="https://www.blog.google/products/maps/maps-15th-birthday/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">marking the occasion</a> with a fresh new icon and fancy features, including: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Prime in-app real estate for your saved locations (more than 6.5 billion have been staked out already) </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A curated feed by local experts and foodies showing users what’s #trending </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>More opportunities for crowdsourced information, including how accessible and sweaty that subway ride will be</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Google Maps made some other big changes in recent months, including adding <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/google-maps-incognito-mode/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Incognito Mode</a> (after the app received flak for storing and sharing user data) and finally bringing over one of the most popular features from Google’s other navigation app Waze: highlighting speed traps. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Finding a paper map in your grandparents’ Mercury sedan is like pulling out a 20th century Rosetta stone. Mobile apps like Google’s have helped billions of people travel more efficiently.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here:</strong> Google unveiled Street View in 2007 and put in 110% effort making sure every nook and cranny on Earth made it in there. </p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
QUIZ
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/06/brews-weekly-news-quiz-february-7?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
State of the Quiz
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">More volatile than Tesla stock. Counts faster than Iowa. Could really use a MacBook Pro. It's the Brew's Weekly News Quiz. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">1. Real estate vet Sandeep Mathrani is taking over as CEO of which company formerly led by a not-real estate vet? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">2. In 83 days, Disney+’s user base grew from zero to 28.6 million. Is that <strong style="color:#000">greater or less</strong> <strong style="color:#000">than</strong> 35% of Netflix’s user base? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">3. <strong style="color:#000">Fill in the blank: </strong>The hedge fund Pershing Square is holding on to its investment in ________ and is encouraged by the restaurant chain’s “clear plan to drive continued progress.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">4. Which fast food chain is “hand-cracking fresh eggs” for a new breakfast menu?</p>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In-N-Out Burger</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Wendy’s</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Bojangles’</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Burger King</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">5. The “Las Vegas of Asia” is shutting down casinos for two weeks because of the coronavirus outbreak. What’s the semiautonomous territory called? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em><strong style="color:#000">Answers: </strong>1. WeWork 2. Less than; Disney+’s is 17% the size of Netflix’s 3. Chipotle 4. Wendy’s 5. Macau</em></p>

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In today’s Friday Puzzle, we’re diving into the recesses of Reddit for wordplay known as a “<a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/WordAvalanches/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Word Avalanche</a>.” It is defined as a “highly contrived sentence, where many syllable sounds are repeated via the use of wordplay and/or puns.”<strong style="color:#000"></strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Here’s an example clue: </strong></span><span>Rarely do fathers peddle stupid trinkets. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Here’s an example answer: </strong></span><span>Seldom do dads sell dumb doodads. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Let’s play.</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The explosive dinosaur may perish. He lacks strength. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>People from Northern Europe preserved a bird inside a tin. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>I bet my sister my breakfast that the skin on my toes doesn’t duplicate its DNA.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Will of Bel Air, we now see you as a ridiculous genie. *Writes critique* “That trailer was terrible!”</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Keep scrolling for the answers. </em></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nREAL ESTATE \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/06/nycs-new-broker-fee-rule-means?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nNYC Is Feeling StreetUneasy\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"New York City apartment \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTgxMDI4NTgxLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNew York City has about 5.6 million renters, and if you gather them all in one room, you’ll end up with roughly 5.6 million complaints and 0.5 nice things to say. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs one of the most expensive rental markets in the world, the city’s real estate “quirks”—like skyscraper-high broker fees—have angered renters for years. But that might be changing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBroker or broken\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast year, state regulators passed renter protections that capped application fees at $20 and security deposits at one month’s rent. On Tuesday night, they clarified those rules and casually slipped in an announcement that \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/05/nyregion/nyc-landlord-rental-broker-fees.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erenters can no longer be charged\u003c/a\u003e broker fees, the NYT reports. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat are those? \u003c/strong\u003eBrokers manage apartment listings, viewing appointments, and leases. They have almighty leverage over NYC renters because 1) inventory is so tight and 2) many landlords choose not to list units directly or deal with annoying prospective tenants. For their services, brokers collect fees of up to 15% of the annual lease. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eFor context, in December 2019 \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.elliman.com/pdf/292b1b03c463ef570869fa2e601de1ef307d0a22?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaverage monthly rent\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e was $4,412 in Manhattan, $3,410 in Brooklyn, and $3,022 in Queens, according to Douglas Elliman. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBrokers can still collect fees, but they’ll have to pry it from landlords. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eMore controversial than a cinnamon and lox bagel?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eProponents of the change say it will protect tenants, lower barriers to housing, and reduce NYC's homeless population.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut critics—otherwise known as the real estate industry—have other thoughts. They claim the rule will disproportionately hurt small building owners who rely on brokers and upend a system that sustains 25,000+ licensed brokers. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOthers predict the fees will be passed down to tenants by landlords raising prices. Around 1 million apartments in the city are rent-regulated, but 900,000+ aren’t—and those units could potentially \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/alyyale/2020/02/06/nyc-renters-say-goodbye-to-broker-fees-landlords-poised-to-pick-up-the-slack/#32415d3b15a4?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eface higher rents\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe Real Estate Board of New York threatened to challenge the rule on legal grounds. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, mattress-by-mail company Casper Sleep \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/casper-prices-ipo-222615705.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid Shares gained 12.5% on the day, but that's like scoring a goal when you're already down 6–0. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCasper opened for trading at $14.50 per share when it had initially aimed to go public at a range of $17-$19.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn 2019, private investors gave Casper a valuation of $1.1 billion. It began yesterday with a valuation of less than $600 million.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Hotshot startups are answering for years of bloated private valuations. Last year’s crop of IPOs featured a series of massive, unprofitable companies (see: Uber, Lyft, Peloton) that tripped and fell when subjected to public scrutiny. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe disrupter may become the disrupted—Casper isn’t just competing with Big Mattress anymore. Dozens of upstarts like Purple and Walmart’s Allswell \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/05/casper-cuts-expected-ipo-price-range-to-12-13-a-share-from-17-19-a-share.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eare now vying\u003c/a\u003e for a spot in the “sleep economy.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/elliott-management-builds-more-than-2-5-billion-stake-in-softbank-11581015340?mod=breakingnews\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethree new pieces of info\u003c/a\u003e about the activist hedge fund Elliott Management, courtesy of the WSJ. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eElliott has invested over $2.5 billion in Japanese conglomerate SoftBank. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eElliott ratcheted up that investment recently. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eElliott has politely weighed in on SoftBank’s portfolio and governance decisions. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eElliott’s advice to SoftBank\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor one, buy back stock. Elliott \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/06/elliott-management-invests-more-than-2point5-billion-in-softbank-wsj.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erecommended repurchasing\u003c/a\u003e $10–$20 billion to close the not-tiny gap between SoftBank’s market value and the value of its stakes in major players like Chinese internet giant Alibaba, Uber, and Slack. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSecond, Elliott is reportedly pushing SoftBank to improve transparency and investment decisions at its controversial $100 billion Vision Fund.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eElliott is known for bossing bosses around. Founded and owned by billionaire Paul Singer, Elliott isn’t shy about telling the Jack Dorseys of the world how to tie their Allbirds. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTomorrow night Google Maps will celebrate 15 years of helping roadtrippers find their way to the nearest public #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emarking the occasion\u003c/a\u003e with a fresh new icon and fancy features, including: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePrime in-app real estate for your saved locations (more than 6.5 billion have been staked out already) \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eA curated feed by local experts and foodies showing users one of the most popular features from Google’s other navigation app Waze: highlighting speed traps. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eFinding a paper map in your grandparents’ Mercury sedan is like
